text: Thomas Wiemann. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Wiemann T (2023). kcmeans: Conditional Expectation Function Estimation K-Conditional-Means. R package version 0.1.0.9000, https://github.com/thomaswiemann/kcmeans.
code: @Manual{,   title = {kcmeans: Conditional Expectation Function Estimation with K-Conditional-Means},   author = {Thomas Wiemann},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0.9000},   url = {https://github.com/thomaswiemann/kcmeans}, }

what: Conditional Expectation Function Estimation with K-Conditional-Means
title: Conditional Expectation Function Estimation with K-Conditional-Means
text: kcmeans implementation K-Conditional-Means (KCMeans) regression estimator analyzed Wiemann (2023; arxiv:2311.17021) conditional expectation function estimation using categorical features. implementation leverages unconditional KMeans implementation one dimension using dynamic programming Ckmeans.1d.dp package. See working paper Optimal Categorical Instrumental Variables discussion KCMeans estimator.

title: Conditional Expectation Function Estimation with K-Conditional-Means
text: Install latest development version GitHub (requires devtools package): Install latest public release CRAN:

title: Conditional Expectation Function Estimation with K-Conditional-Means
text: illustrate kcmeans, consider simulating small dataset continuous outcome variable y, two observed predictors – categorical variable Z continuous variable X – (unobserved) Gaussian error. Wiemann (2023), reduced form unobserved lower-dimensional representation dependent latent categorical variable Z0. kcmeans computed combining categorical feature continuous feature. default, categorical feature first column. Alternatively, column corresponding categorical feature can set via which_is_cat argument. Computation quick – indeed dynamic programming algorithm leveraged Ckmeans.1d.dp package polynomial number values taken categorical feature Z. See also ?kcmeans details. may now use predict.kcmeans method construct fitted values /compute predictions lower-dimensional latent categorical feature Z0. See also ?predict.kcmeans details. Finally, also straightforward compute standard errors final coefficients, e.g., using summary.lm:
code: # Load package library(kcmeans) # Set seed set.seed(51944) # Sample parameters nobs = 800 # sample size # Sample data X <- rnorm(nobs) Z <- sample(1:20, nobs, replace = T) Z0 <- Z %% 4 # lower-dimensional latent categorical variable y <- Z0 + X + rnorm(nobs) system.time({ kcmeans_fit <- kcmeans(y = y, X = cbind(Z, X), K = 4) }) #>    user  system elapsed  #>    1.19    0.12    2.11 # Predicted values for the outcome + R^2 y_hat <- predict(kcmeans_fit, cbind(Z, X)) round(1 - mean((y - y_hat)^2) / mean((y - mean(y))^2), 3) #> [1] 0.695  # Predicted values for the latent categorical feature + missclassification rate Z0_hat <- predict(kcmeans_fit, cbind(Z, X), clusters = T) - 1 mean((Z0 - Z0_hat)!=0) #> [1] 0 # Compute the linear regression object and call summary.lm lm_fit <- lm(y ~ as.factor(Z0_hat) + X) summary(lm_fit) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = y ~ as.factor(Z0_hat) + X) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -3.1205 -0.6916  0.0544  0.6700  3.4201  #>  #> Coefficients: #>                    Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)         0.03897    0.07434   0.524      0.6     #> as.factor(Z0_hat)1  0.88393    0.10265   8.611   <2e-16 *** #> as.factor(Z0_hat)2  1.88314    0.10271  18.334   <2e-16 *** #> as.factor(Z0_hat)3  3.01094    0.10636  28.310   <2e-16 *** #> X                   1.04636    0.03541  29.549   <2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 1.03 on 795 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.6954, Adjusted R-squared:  0.6939  #> F-statistic: 453.7 on 4 and 795 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Conditional Expectation Function Estimation with K-Conditional-Means
text: Since cardinality support underlying low-dimensional latent categorical variable often unknown, useful consider multiple KCMeans estimators varying values K. code snippet uses ddml package compute cross-validation mean-square prediction error (MSPE) three KCMeans estimators (see also ?ddml::crossval details). addition, KCMeans MSPEs compared MSPE three alternative conditional expectation function estimators: Ordinary least squares (see also ?ddml::ols) Lasso cross-validated penalty parameter (see also ?ddml::mdl_glmnet) Ridge cross-validated penalty parameter results show KCMeans K=4 K=6 achieve smallest MSPE among considered estimators.
code: # load the ddml package library(ddml)  # one-hot encoding for ols, lasso, and ridge Z_indicators <- model.matrix(~ as.factor(Z))   # Combine features and create indices X_all <- cbind(Z, X, Z_indicators) indx_factor <- 1:2 indx_indicators <- 2:(2 + ncol(Z_indicators))  # Create the learners, assign indicators to ols, lasso, and ridge learner_list <- list(list(fun = kcmeans,                           args = list(K = 2),                           assign_X = indx_factor),                      list(fun = kcmeans,                           args = list(K = 4),                           assign_X = indx_factor),                      list(fun = kcmeans,                           args = list(K = 6),                           assign_X = indx_factor),                      list(fun = ols,                           assign_X = indx_indicators),                      list(fun = mdl_glmnet,                           assign_X = indx_indicators),                      list(fun = mdl_glmnet,                           args = list(alpha = 0),                           assign_X = indx_indicators))  # Compute the cross-valdiation MSPE cv_res <- crossval(y = y, X = X_all,                     learners = learner_list,                     cv_folds = 20, silent = T) # Print the results names(cv_res$mspe) <- c("KCMeans (K=2)", "KCMeans (K=4)", "KCMeans (K=6)",                         "OLS", "Lasso", "Ridge") round(cv_res$mspe, 4) #> KCMeans (K=2) KCMeans (K=4) KCMeans (K=6)           OLS         Lasso  #>        1.3170        1.0650        1.0655        1.0803        1.0797  #>         Ridge  #>        1.0890  # Which learner is the best? names(which.min(cv_res$mspe)) #> [1] "KCMeans (K=4)"

title: Conditional Expectation Function Estimation with K-Conditional-Means
text: Wiemann T (2023). “Optimal Categorical Instruments.” https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.17021

title: K-Conditional-Means Estimator — kcmeans
text: Implementation K-Conditional-Means estimator.

title: K-Conditional-Means Estimator — kcmeans
text: y outcome variable, numerical vector. X (sparse) feature matrix one column categorical predictor. which_is_cat integer indicating column X corresponds categorical predictor. K number support points, integer greater 2.

title: K-Conditional-Means Estimator — kcmeans
text: kcmeans returns object S3 class kcmeans. object class kcmeans list containing following components: cluster_map matrix characterizes estimated predictor residualized outcome \(\tilde{Y} \equiv Y - X_{2:}^\top \hat{\pi}\). first column x denotes value categorical variable corresponds unrestricted sample mean mean_x \(\tilde{Y}\), sample share p_x, estimated cluster cluster_x, estimated restricted sample mean mean_xK \(\tilde{Y}\) just K support points. mean_y unconditional sample mean \(\tilde{Y}\). pi best linear prediction coefficients \(Y\) \(X\) corresponding non-categorical predictors \(X_{2:}\). which_is_cat,K Passthrough user-provided arguments. See details.

title: K-Conditional-Means Estimator — kcmeans
text: Wang H Song M (2011). "Ckmeans.1d.dp: optimal k-means clustering one dimension dynamic programming." R Journal 3(2), 29--33. Wiemann T (2023). "Optimal Categorical Instruments." https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.17021

title: K-Conditional-Means Estimator — kcmeans
code: # Simulate simple dataset with n=800 observations X <- rnorm(800) # continuous predictor Z <- sample(1:20, 800, replace = TRUE) # categorical predictor Z0 <- Z %% 4 # lower-dimensional latent categorical variable y <- Z0 + X + rnorm(800) # outcome # Compute kcmeans with four support points kcmeans_fit <- kcmeans(y, cbind(Z, X), K = 4) # Print the estimated support points of the categorical predictor print(unique(kcmeans_fit$cluster_map[, "mean_xK"])) #> [1]  0.8919541  1.9124459  3.1148056 -0.1195223

what: Prediction Method for the K-Conditional-Means Estimator. — predict.kcmeans
title: Prediction Method for the K-Conditional-Means Estimator. — predict.kcmeans
text: Prediction method K-Conditional-Means estimator.

title: Prediction Method for the K-Conditional-Means Estimator. — predict.kcmeans
code: # S3 method for kcmeans predict(object, newdata, clusters = FALSE, ...)

title: Prediction Method for the K-Conditional-Means Estimator. — predict.kcmeans
text: object object class kcmeans. newdata (sparse) feature matrix first column corresponds categorical predictor. clusters boolean indicating whether estimated clusters returned. ... Currently unused.

title: Prediction Method for the K-Conditional-Means Estimator. — predict.kcmeans
text: numerical vector predicted values (clusters = FALSE) predicted clusters (clusters = FALSE).

title: Prediction Method for the K-Conditional-Means Estimator. — predict.kcmeans
text: Wiemann T (2023). "Optimal Categorical Instruments." https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.17021

title: Prediction Method for the K-Conditional-Means Estimator. — predict.kcmeans
code: # Simulate simple dataset with n=800 observations X <- rnorm(800) # continuous predictor Z <- sample(1:20, 800, replace = TRUE) # categorical predictor Z0 <- Z %% 4 # lower-dimensional latent categorical variable y <- Z0 + X + rnorm(800) # outcome # Compute kcmeans with four support points kcmeans_fit <- kcmeans(y, cbind(Z, X), K = 4) # Calculate in-sample predictions fitted_values <- predict(kcmeans_fit, cbind(Z, X)) # Print sample share of estimated clusters clusters <- predict(kcmeans_fit, cbind(Z, X), clusters = TRUE) table(clusters) #> clusters #>   1   2   3   4  #> 195 215 199 191
